Caption: Fig. 1. A selection of plots encompassed by the product plots framework. All display the same data (the distribution of happiness and marital status), but each supports a different question. From left to right: mosaic plot, treemap, stacked bar chart, ﬂuctuation diagram, and two new plots that don’t have names. In all plots, area is proportional to probability.

Figure 4 shows three ways to represent the the 2d table of proportions Fig. 2. 1d partitions showing the distribution of happiness. From left to of sex and happiness. The top table displays the joint distribution, right: bars, spines and tiles.

Figure 4 shows three ways to represent the the 2d table of proportions Fig. 2. 1d partitions showing the distribution of happiness. From left to of sex and happiness. The top table displays the joint distribution, right: bars, spines and tiles.

Fig. 4. The distribution of happiness and sex, displayed in three equiv- alent ways. (Top) Joint distribution. Overall table sums to one. (Middle) Conditional distribution of sex given happiness and marginal distribution of happiness. (Bottom) Conditional distribution of happiness given sex and marginal distribution of sex.
Fig. 5. Plots of the distribution of happiness and sex ( male, female) (Left) f (happy), (Middle) f (sex|happy), (Right) f (happy, sex).

Fig. 4. The distribution of happiness and sex, displayed in three equiv- alent ways. (Top) Joint distribution. Overall table sums to one. (Middle) Conditional distribution of sex given happiness and marginal distribution of happiness. (Bottom) Conditional distribution of happiness given sex and marginal distribution of sex.

Fig. 7. (Left) The joint distribution of marital status and age, f (marital, age) as f (marital|age) · f (age), (in decades) partitioned by a vspine and hspine. (Right) The joint distribution of age and marital status, f (age, marital) as f (ageT |marital) · f (marital), partitioned by a vspine and hbar.

Fig. 6. Conditional on marital status, are men or women happier? This ﬁgure shows the construction of f (happy, sex, marital) with (from left to right) a vspine by marital status, a vspine by marital status and sex, and a hspine by marital status, sex and happiness. For all levels of marital status, men are slightly less happy.
Fig. 10. The distribution of happiness with age, f (age, happy). (Left) hbar + vspine: an extension of the histogram. (Right) hspine + vspine: an extension of the spinogram.
Fig. 9. Joint distribution of age and sex ( male, female), f (age, sex). (Left) counts and (right) probability weights. In this case, there is very little difference between the plots.

Fig. 8. (Left) f (happy, health, f inrela) = f (happy|health, f inrela) × f (health, f inrela), partitioned with a vspine and ﬂuct. Health is on the x-axis, ﬁnancial status on the y-axis. (Middle) f (happy|health, f inrela). We can no longer see the joint distribution of health and ﬁnancial status, but it is much easier to see the conditional distribution of happiness. Healthier and richer people are happier: maybe money does buy happiness? (Right) f (happy|health, f inrela) partitioned with a ﬂuct and hspine, emphasizing the relationship of happiness with ﬁnances, whereas the middle plot emphasizes the relationship with health. ( Not too happy, pretty happy, very happy)

Fig. 12. (Top) Area graphics in Cartesian coordinates. (Mid) Area graph- ics in polar coordinates. (Bottom) Product graphics with alternate map- ping of x and y to r and θ . From left to right: hbar + hbar, vspline + hbar, hspine + hspine, hspine + vspine. ( male, female)
